text:
East River--River Scenes: Sailing vessels docked on South Street wharfage. No. 1, showing the Produce Exchange Tower, is at Moore Street, while No. 2 is at Jones Lane.

Early 1900's
Views 1,2

Thomas W. Kennedy Collection
Through Beecher Ogden
Museum Photographers Association
Grand Central Terminal
title: East River scenes.

text:
4 and 5 South Street, adjoining and west of the N. W. corner of Moore Street. The corner building, the South Ferry Hotel is on the right and is not shown.

February 19, 1915

Warts Brothers

6-7 South Street, at the N. W. corner of Moore Street, showing the South Ferry Hotel.

February 19, 1915

Wurts Brothers

6-7 South Street, at the N. W. corner of Moore Street, showing the South Ferry Hotel.

February 19, 1915

Wurts Brothers

(1) 8 to 13 South Street, north side, east from Moore, to Broad Streets. On the extreme right, is partially shown the Broad Street Hospital, on the N.E. corner of Broad Street.

February 23, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a more inclusive view of the Broad Street Hospital. Shown, in the background, are (right to left), the 60 Wall Street tower, Farmer's Loan and Trust Co. Building, and the Bank of Manhattan Building.

November 23, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) A portion of the same, showing only Nos. 8, 9 and 10.

November 20, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

7 to 1 South Street, north side, west from, but not including Moore, to and including Whitehall Streets, showing the lower parts of the building's. Also shown (background), is the South Ferry station of the Second, Third, Sixth and Ninth Aves. Elevated lines, (all lines converge at this junction.

August 4, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

South Street, north side, east across Moore Street, showing the buildings that face the East River at the foot of Manhattan. The prominent building shown is the Broad Street Hospital. Beyond is the Seamens Church Institute. View 2 is limited to the Moore to Broad Street frontage. Across the top, from left to right are the International Telephone, Bank of Manhattan, City Bank-Farmers Trust, and Sixth Wall Tower buildings.

1: Sept. 13, 1938
2: May 20, 1939

P. L. Sperr

South Street, north side, east across Moore Street, showing the buildings that face the East River at the foot of Manhattan. The prominent building shown is the Broad Street Hospital. Beyond is the Seamens Church Institute. View 2 is limited to the Moore to Broad Street frontage. Across the top, from left to right are the International Telephone, Bank of Manhattan, City Bank-Farmers Trust, and Sixth Wall Tower buildings.

1: Sept. 13, 1938
2: May 20, 1939

P. L. Sperr

Moore Street, north from South Street. View 1 shows an extended perspective on the west side of this narrow thoroughfare. The South Ferry division of the Second and Third Avenue's Elevated Line runs on Front Street. Directly above same appears a corner of the nine story U.S. Army Building. View 2 details the N. E. corner of Moore and South Street's. No. 8 South Street has been removed. This was identical with No. 9, the adjoining building. Above the roof of the latter are the upper portions of the International Telephone Bldg., the Bank of Manhattan Bldg., and the City Bank - Farmers Trust Bldg.

May 20, 1939
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr

Moore Street, north from South Street. View 1 shows an extended perspective on the west side of this narrow thoroughfare. The South Ferry division of the Second and Third Avenue's Elevated Line runs on Front Street. Directly above same appears a corner of the nine story U.S. Army Building. View 2 details the N. E. corner of Moore and South Street's. No. 8 South Street has been removed. This was identical with No. 9, the adjoining building. Above the roof of the latter are the upper portions of the International Telephone Bldg., the Bank of Manhattan Bldg., and the City Bank - Farmers Trust Bldg.

May 20, 1939
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr
